\title{Schemes Sheet 2}
\author{Franz Miltz}

\maketitle

\section*{Question 5b}

Consider the schemes $X=\Spec\mathbb{Z}[t]$ and $Y=\Spec\mathbb{Z}[u]$.
Then the inclusions $\mathbb{Z}[t]\subset\mathbb{Z}[t^\pm]$ and
$\mathbb{Z}[u]\subset\mathbb{Z}[u^\pm]$ induce subschemes
$U=\Spec\mathbb{Z}[t^\pm]\subset X$ and
$V=\Spec\mathbb{Z}[u^\pm]\subset Y$. Moreover, the ring isomorphism
$t\mapsto{u}^{-1}$ induces an isomorphism of schemes $\phi:U\to V$.
We may thus glue $X$ and $Y$ along $\phi$ to obtain a new schemes
$Z=X\sqcup_\phi Y$. Note that the cocycle condition is trivially satisfied.

\begin{proposition}
  $\mathcal O_Z(Z)=\mathbb{Z}$.
  \begin{proof}
    Firstly, note that the structure sheaf $\mathcal O_Z$ is constructed
    so that we have a commutative diagram
    \begin{equation}
      % https://q.uiver.app/#
      \begin{tikzcd}
  & {\mathcal O_Z(Z)} \\
        {\mathcal O_Z(X)} && {\mathcal O_Z(Y)} \\
        {\mathcal O_X(X)} && {\mathcal O_Y(Y)} \\
        {\mathcal O_X(U)} && {\mathcal O_Y(V)}
        \arrow["\cong"', from=2-1, to=3-1]
        \arrow["\cong", from=2-3, to=3-3]
        \arrow["{\rho_U}"', from=3-1, to=4-1]
        \arrow["{\rho_V}", from=3-3, to=4-3]
        \arrow["{\rho_X}"', from=1-2, to=2-1]
        \arrow["{\rho_Y}", from=1-2, to=2-3]
        \arrow["{\phi}", from=4-3, to=4-1]
      \end{tikzcd}
    \end{equation}
    Explicitly, this is
    \begin{equation}
      % https://q.uiver.app/#
      \begin{tikzcd}
  & {\mathcal O_Z(Z)} \\
        {\mathcal O_Z(X)} && {\mathcal O_Z(Y)} \\
        {\mathbb Z[t]} && {\mathbb Z[u]} \\
        {\mathbb Z[t^\pm]} && {\mathbb Z[u^\pm]}
        \arrow["\cong"', from=2-1, to=3-1]
        \arrow["\cong", from=2-3, to=3-3]
        \arrow[hook, from=3-1, to=4-1]
        \arrow[hook, from=3-3, to=4-3]
        \arrow["{\rho_X}"', from=1-2, to=2-1]
        \arrow["{\rho_Y}", from=1-2, to=2-3]
        \arrow["\phi", from=4-3, to=4-1]
      \end{tikzcd}
    \end{equation}
    Thus a section $s\in\mathcal O_Z(Z)$ is defined by its
    restrictions to elements $\res{s}{X}\in\mathbb{Z}[t]$ and
    $\res{s}{Y}\in\mathbb{Z}[u]$ which must satisfy
    $\res{s}{X}=\phi(\res{s}{Y})$. Note that
    $\phi(\mathbb{Z}[u])=\mathbb{Z}[{t}^{-1}]$
    so $f\in\mathbb{Z}[t]\cap\mathbb{Z}[{t}^{-1}]=\mathbb{Z}$.
    Similarly, $g\in\mathbb{Z}[u]\cap\mathbb{Z}[{u}^{-1}]$.
    Finally, $\res{\phi}{\mathbb{Z}}=\identity$, completing the proof.
  \end{proof}
\end{proposition}

\section*{Question 5c}

Consider the same setup as above except $\phi(t) = u$.

\begin{proposition}
  $\mathcal O_Z(Z)=\mathbb{Z}$.
  \begin{proof}
    We obtain the diagram
    \begin{equation}
      % https://q.uiver.app/#
      \begin{tikzcd}
  & {\mathcal O_Z(Z)} \\
        {\mathcal O_Z(X)} && {\mathcal O_Z(Y)} \\
        {\mathbb Z[t]} && {\mathbb Z[u]} \\
        {\mathbb Z[t^\pm]} && {\mathbb Z[u^\pm]}
        \arrow["\cong"', from=2-1, to=3-1]
        \arrow["\cong", from=2-3, to=3-3]
        \arrow[hook, from=3-1, to=4-1]
        \arrow["{\rho_X}"', from=1-2, to=2-1]
        \arrow["{\rho_Y}", from=1-2, to=2-3]
        \arrow[hook, from=3-3, to=4-3]
        \arrow[Rightarrow, no head, from=4-1, to=4-3]
      \end{tikzcd}
    \end{equation}
    Once again a section $s\in\mathcal O_Z(Z)$ is defined by its
    restrictions to elements $\res{s}{X}\in\mathbb{Z}[t]$ and
    $\res{s}{Y}\in\mathbb{Z}[u]$ which must satisfy
    $\res{s}{X}=\phi(\res{s}{Y})$.
    Noting $\phi(\mathbb{Z}[t])=\mathbb{Z}[u]$ it follows
  \end{proof}
\end{proposition}
